Paolo "Nusco" Perrotta wrote:

>  > I've started investigating JUnit and I'm finding that for methods in my
>  > application that have some non trivial logic (basically multiple if paths
>  > through the method) that my JUnit tests are becoming unwieldy to 
> setup and
>  > maintain. I'm retrofitting unit tests onto an existing large J2EE app.
> 
> To me, one of the benefits of tests is that they help me to spot design
> problems early. Whenever I find it difficult to write a test for a method, I
> ask myself whether it's the method's fault.

I would estimate that 99% of the time -- no hyperbole -- the problem is 
Too Many Responsibilities. As to whether you can conveniently refactor, 
that is another issue.

Try garden-variety Extract Method. If a method has too many codepaths, 
extract the smallest, innermost part you could reasonably test on its 
own, make it public, then test it in isolation. Repeat until happy.
